title: Harvest Timing and Environmental Conditions

requirements.question: Are there criteria for determining when fields are suitable for harvest entry (e.g., after rain, irrigation, or pesticide application)?
Are appropriate waiting periods observed after water application events before harvest begins?
Are pesticide pre-harvest intervals (PHI) and re-entry intervals (REI) documented and strictly followed?
requirements.automaticFailureReason: Failure to observe pesticide intervals creates chemical residue violations and worker safety hazards.

requirements.question: Is there a system to communicate field clearance status to harvest supervisors before harvest begins?
Are adverse weather conditions considered in harvest decisions to minimize contamination risk?

mandatoryStatements: Criteria must be established for determining when fields are suitable and safe for harvest entry, considering factors such as recent irrigation, rainfall, flooding, or pesticide applications.
Appropriate waiting periods must be observed after significant water application events to allow fields to drain and reduce microbial contamination risk.
Pesticide pre-harvest intervals (PHI) and worker re-entry intervals (REI) must be strictly documented and followed before harvest operations begin.
A communication system must be in place to verify and document field clearance status before harvest crews are authorized to enter fields.
Harvest timing decisions must consider weather conditions that may increase contamination risk such as high winds, dust storms, or proximity to flooding.
capaInject: Develop a field clearance protocol requiring written authorization from qualified personnel before harvest crews can enter any field.
Establish documented waiting periods after irrigation or rain events based on crop type, soil conditions, and water source to minimize microbial risk.
Implement a pesticide tracking system that clearly shows PHI and REI compliance with sign-off verification before harvest authorization.
Create a field status board or digital system that displays clearance status, restrictions, and expected clearance dates for all production areas.
Define adverse weather protocols including suspension criteria, assessment procedures, and clearance requirements before harvest can resume.
traceabilityInject: Maintain field clearance records including field ID, clearance date/time, authorizing person, criteria met, and any restrictions or special handling requirements.
Document all pesticide applications with product name, application date/time, PHI, REI, and calculated clearance date before harvest.
Keep records of significant water events (irrigation, rain, flooding) including date, amount, source, and waiting period applied before harvest.
Log any harvest delays or suspensions due to weather or field conditions including reason, duration, and resumption authorization.
Track communication of field status to harvest supervisors including method (radio, text, meeting), time, recipient, and acknowledgment.
micro_inject: Emphasize that harvesting too soon after irrigation or rain can introduce waterborne pathogens present in irrigation water or splash contamination from soil.
Ensure harvest timing protocols account for the increased microbial load on plant surfaces following water application events.
Implement monitoring to verify that adequate drying time prevents harvest equipment and workers from transferring soil and water contamination to product.
Verify that field clearance procedures prevent harvest during conditions that increase pathogen transfer risk through environmental contamination.
Monitor compliance with waiting periods to ensure product safety while balancing operational needs and product quality requirements.
